text:
And thanks to all of you
for coming to my talk. So my name is Mayank Goel.

As Michael said, I'm a
faculty member at CMU. And today I'll talk
about a bit of our work

in this broadly described title
here, A Billion Medical Devices.

Really, it's more than a
billion devices at this point. Because we are using smartphones
and watches and other consumer

devices that we have with us. And I'll focus more
within that area, on using far from perfect
machine learning in health care,

and far from perfect sensing and
machine learning in health care. Because there are a
lot of limitations

that we have in terms of
sensing, machine learning, use of AI. But we want to make sure
that we can figure out

ways to support users in
maintaining better health while using these technologies.

Because we can't wait
for them to get perfect. Because that might
not ever happen.

This is the most significant
bit that I wanted to cover, that you know who I am. You know my lab name.

You know the title of the slide. So I'm not too worried whether
I get through all of my slides

or not. So if you have any questions
at any point, just ask. We don't need to
worry about time.

So keeping people healthy
at home, why is that needed?

It turns out that we
are living longer. The average life
expectancy has increased.

But at the same time, we are
living with more illnesses. We go to doctors
whenever we are ill.

But we also manage our illnesses
at home between those visits to the doctor. And the doctor is
also not always there.

The access to health
care is limited. Wherever we go, the magnitude
of limit to the doctor

is going to be different
in different contexts, in different countries. And COVID was
definitely one phenomena

that happened that
stress-tested the health systems across the globe. Did not matter how rich you
are, what part of the world

you are in, everyone felt
some lack of health care at that point. So this photo is from the
delta wave of COVID-19

from India, where
most of my family is. And during this wave, at one
point, everyone in my family

got COVID. Everyone recovered. My mom was the one who
was affected the most

and became very sick. And at one point, she was
in ICU for three, four days. But before she was in ICU--

and this was like everyone in
my family, my brother, his wife, my dad, mom,
everyone had COVID--

and the doctor said, keep
track of her breathing rate.

If her breathing rate goes
above 20 breaths per minute, then bring her to the hospital.

Because the hospitals were
insanely inundated with patients as well. So the doctors wanted to
be a bit more strategic in

who comes to the
hospital and who not. So 20 breaths per minute was the
threshold that the doctors gave.

And that is hard for
you to keep track of, especially when you are
sick as well with COVID.

But my father and my brother,
they all live together.

They were able to make it
work during the daytime. At night, they could not. Because they had
to sleep as well.

They were recovering
from an illness as well. I was here in the
US, in Pittsburgh.

The time zone difference
meant that at night I could observe her.

But I had to manually do it. So initially it started as a
FaceTime call, that my dad would

start the call on a laptop
that my brother had, would align the camera to
where my mom was sleeping.

And I'll keep an eye. But it became tedious. I had done a lot of work on
health sensing until then.

In fact, I had a paper
on using wireless routers for measuring breathing
rate, five years

before my mom needed it. But I still did not have it. Because when we write
a paper on something

and what is really usable and
deployable in a person's life, there is a big gap there.

So around that time, I was
teaching a course on sensing and machine learning. And one of the homeworks that
students do in that class

is using cameras for
measuring heart rate. While I was doing that,
I realized that wait,

this algorithm that
we are using here can be used to detect
breathing as well. So I'll show you a quick video
of that system in action.

That's an angry-looking me. It's just angry-looking. I'm not really angry. I'm just anxious about whether
the video I wanted to record,

I'll be able to record or not. So apart from that angry me,
you see some dots in this video.

This is the output of
optical flow algorithm. Many of you might
be aware of it. But for those of
us who do not, it's

an algorithm that
basically tracks motion in different parts of a video. So those small lines
or dots that you see,

as I move around
in this video, you will see these
lines moving around. So they move with me.

As I move from left to right,
they move left to right. I move up and down,
they move up and down.

Now, if I add just simple
addition of the vector of each

of these dots and lines that
I have, into a single stream, I can track the direction
and the amount of motion

in this video.  Started looking there. So here, you see
a person sleeping.

And that white squiggly
that we see in the middle is just a simple addition
with very basic filtering.

On top of that is basically the
breathing rate of that person. And this is 15 lines of code
that can run on a browser.

So I basically gave this
small web app to my dad. He ran it on that laptop.

And I was able to keep track
of my mom's breathing rate when she had COVID
for those three days.

It worked like a charm. But why did it
work like a charm? Who's the user here?
Who do you think is the user?

You have experience
with technology, so you know that the
little ones don't matter.

It's the big ones. But somebody who hasn't
looked at a graph in 40 years would have no idea
what to do with that.

Yeah, so I'm the user. I'm the expert here
who's able to use it. So yeah, I'm the user.

And you are right, I'm
the expert as well. But I'm also rich by
Pittsburgh standards.

I don't think I'm rich
by California standards. [LAUGHTER] I'm also motivated because it's
my mom's health online here.

I'm trained to use. And as you said,
I'm trying to change to build these systems as well.

I would figure out
ways to support myself. So it worked for me
because I'm an expert user.

But one of the ethos of
HCII, especially at CMU, is that the user is not like me.

The average user is
not going to be rich, motivated, trained to build,
trained to use this system.

So as we want to build these
smart end-to-end health systems, we need to make sure
that we sense things

in a way that are explainable. In that video, I
was using a camera. It was not a Wi-Fi
router that is

trying to measure breathing rate
that an untrained user would not know what to do. If I tell someone who does not
know computer vision that I'm

trying to measure
something with a camera, and they can look at the
output of the camera, it would be obvious to
them that, OK, you have

to align the camera somehow. You have to make sure
it's not occluded. No one comes in front of it. The lighting
conditions are there.

There are things
that we would know, because the camera is
mimicking human senses.

So we try to make sure in many
cases that the sensing we use is explainable to
the untrained user.

It won't always be accurate. The machine learning
won't be accurate. So when needed, we'll
need to seek user input.

The information that
the system generates

should be actionable
and useful for the user because that then only they
will provide you the input.

They will give you their
interest and time and attention. And while doing all
of that, of course,

we need to make sure that we
keep the burden on the user as low as possible. And we try to make
sure that we do

these things across this
end-to-end spectrum of health sensing. So in my group, we
build techniques

to measure health outcomes,
physiology, behavior, et cetera. We figure out ways
to effectively share

that information with the
patient, their family members, caregivers.

We also figure out
ways to explain whatever we have measured
to all the stakeholders.

And then ultimately
try to figure out strategies to help them as
well to take care of themselves and their patients.

So I'll show you some
examples of some of the work that we have done in this area. So I'll start with this idea
of explainable measurements.

And I'll go back to the
breathing rate detection example. Here, instead of using
a regular camera,

we are using a thermal camera. Because a regular camera could
give us how the body is moving.

And from that, we could
extract breathing rate. But it doesn't always work. Because it works when someone is
sleeping, and there is very few

other sources of motion. But in daily life,
it will be hard. If I had a camera
right now that had to monitor my breathing
rate right now,

it will be hard
because I'm talking. I'm also moving. So the thermal camera
is much better at that.

If you see at that
video there, you can see the color of
the nostril changing. That's when we breathe in.

There is evaporation that
happens around nostrils and lips that the camera can pick up.

When we exhale, the
air that is exhaled out is usually going
to be a bit warmer. So we can pick that up as well.

So with that information, we
can really very reliably start extracting breathing rate.

And in this case, the
video was recorded when the camera was placed on a
treadmill and a stationary bike.

And we were looking
at a person's nose as they were exercising. So the first thing we tried
to do with this information

was actually to figure out
how many calories does someone burn when they are exercising. And the reason for that is, the
smartwatches that we regularly

use to figure out how many
calories we have burned are very, very inaccurate. How many of you have
ever seen the number that

shows up on our
watches or phones on how many calories do we burn? I see a few hand raises.

Does anyone know how
inaccurate they are? They are very inaccurate. They are almost 40% inaccurate.

We compare that to
a clinical device that I had to almost
smuggle from somewhere,

because I'm not allowed
to buy those devices and CMU could not figure
out a way on time.

So we compared that
to a smartwatch. We got around 50 participants
to come and exercise

on these machines. And we look at the number. And it was around
40% inaccurate.

In comparison, when you add
the breathing rate information, that error goes down to 5%.

And the reason is, the clinical
device looks at three things-- heart rate, breathing rate,
and the concentration of oxygen

left in the exhaled air. Because our body used
some of the oxygen, converted that to
carbon dioxide.

But it's not pure carbon
dioxide that come out. The thermal camera would
not give us that part. That's why there is still
some error that is left.

But a lot of it goes away. That was one
application we built on top of this thermal imaging
way of measuring respiration.

But we took it further. And one of the things that
I had done in the past using the wireless routers approach
was to look at sleep apnea,

and look at breathing
rate detection there. I'm curious. So I know that the
Apple Watch has

some sort of a measure of
respiratory rate, I think. I imagine it's super inaccurate.

But I think that the user
friendliness of the Apple

watches, so I don't have to have
a camera on me all the time, do you have any thoughts about
the efficacy versus burden

on the user, like trade-off
with these kinds of systems? Yeah, that's a great question. I do not think it
would make sense

in its current form for a
thermal sensing-based approach to be on a smartwatch,
or even on a smartphone.

We connected it to a
smartphone because it was easy to connect to a thermal
camera accessory to that.

I really think the work that
I showed there makes sense to be as part of bike computers
by Garmin and these companies

and on treadmills. So I think that is a use
case, because then it is looking at you all the time. Beyond that, we
just need to know

that our smartwatches at this
point are 40% inaccurate. And we just-- whatever
number we see,

we just subtract out of that. But yes, I think we are not
at that deployable level yet.

So we looked at sleep apnea. Because if any one of you have
ever been to a sleep clinic--

I actually spent
a couple of nights there because we wanted to
see how bad the system looks

right now. But they connect you to
these hundreds of wires. And then you sleep. The signals the doctors get
from this is very useful.

But it is very inconvenient
for the patients. But if you have to do it for
a night or two in a year,

it's fine. The challenge is,
in many places, the access to sleep
clinics is very, very bad.

For example, we are right now
collecting some data in India, in New Delhi. And the hospital
we are working with

is one of the biggest
hospitals in the world. They get patients from
all around the country. And the wait time, I'm not
making this up, for that sleep
clinic is more than a year. So it is really hard.

The access to this
information is really low. And you can get devices
that you can do it at home.

But then they are also
expensive, inaccurate, and also, as you can see, not
very comfortable.

So instead of that, what
we are right now doing is we have collected data from
around 200 patients, where

we give them a thermal camera. Right now, all of this is
happening in the sleep clinic, because we want
synchronized information

from the clinical
devices as well. But you can, while
they are sleeping, you can see the
same kind of signal

that I showed in
the previous video. But because we are
using thermal imaging, it's something we can do beyond
just the nostrils as well.

So we don't always
just sleep like this, and the camera can
keep looking at us. We twist and turn.

When we do that, the
reflected signal, you can actually see
it on the pillow. And if someone covers
their face with a blanket,

as long as it's a
thin enough blanket, you can see the reflections
on that blanket as well. So by combining this information
with the motion information,

because the motion
information is still useful, we can make a very accurate
estimator of sleep apnea.

Not as accurate as
the clinical device, but much more accurate
than the existing devices

that people may use at home. So here, I have a bit of one
example signal that we have.

So the top signal that you
see-- the x-axis is time so the signals are
changing over time-- is the nostril airflow.

And the bottom one is
the chest movement. So what you can see is that when
someone had a sleep apnea event,

their chest is still
moving, but the air is not coming out of the nostrils. Because they are trying
to push the air out,

but there is some
restriction that is not allowing the air to come out. This is something the
doctors want to detect.

But if you use an approach
that only uses motion sensing, you won't get that. So the multimodal approach
allows us to do that.

And the promise of
that meant that we were able to record
this, all of this data. And we are still getting
two patients every night

data from this hospital
in New Delhi in India. So this is the first
example of the things

that I wanted to show you today
on this end-to-end spectrum. How does that differ
from prior work on that?

Or are they only using-- Yeah, only using. [INTERPOSING VOICES] Are those on video
or now like the ones

I guess she wasn't [INAUDIBLE] Yeah, so they are
Wi-Fi based approaches.

All they are able to look at
is how the body is moving. You don't get information
of the nostril airflow.

You can combine that. And the other challenges,
because the way you are sensing is much more impressive when you
are able to use Wi-Fi routers,

but the challenge is that
it's a very indirect approach. When it doesn't work, you don't
know why is it not working.

So oftentimes,
those systems only work when the person
is absolutely still.

If there is any motion, you
don't know what happened. And if you are multiple
people sleeping in the room,

it becomes very confused. People are able to beamform
those Wi-Fi signals and say,

I'll only look at the
left side of the bed. But imagine using something
like this for small kids. I have two kids.

They sleep together
on a big bed. They sleep in one arrangement. In the morning, they are
in a different arrangement.

So an indirect approach would
not be able to detect that. So that's why I'm
advocating for more

direct ways of sensing things. You still need to think of the
privacy aspects of these things.

But there are going
to be trade-offs across all of these approaches.

So now, I'm going to change the
trajectory and the topic a bit, and give you an example of
some of the work we have

done around behavioral sensing. Because that is a
bit more mature work. And I'll be able to
show you examples

where we have gone on this
spectrum of measuring, sharing, and explaining, helping people
take care of themselves.

And the first domain
I'll briefly share is around depression
in college students. I think all of us here
are at a university.

We know that depression
is a huge problem across the whole globe. The average in the US is around
30% in big top universities

like Stanford. CMU, this number is even higher. And oftentimes
students are confused

between stress and depression. So we wanted to see
if we could figure out a way to noninvasively
measure depression.

And we looked at
signals that we can get from consumer devices
like Fitbits, smartwatches,

and phones. And we looked at these six
sources of information,

such as the sleep
sensor, that because one of the symptoms for depression
is trouble sleeping or sleeping

too much, step counts to look
at fatigue and loss of energy,

physical locations that people
have in for social interactions, and fatigue. And overall,
different information

that could provide us
information about or insights into reduced social
interactions.

So we collected this data using
Fitbits and smartwatches for 138 first-year students at CMU--

college students. And we collected this data for
the 16-week-long semester that

we had at CMU. And we collected
all the sensor data that I mentioned, for the
duration of these 16 weeks.

At the beginning and at
the end of the semester, we also did surveys
that the psychiatrists

do with their patients, to
check the starting depression levels that students had
and their depression levels

at the end of the semester. In our cohort,
around 45% students

showed depression symptoms. And unfortunately, no one got
better throughout the semester.

Some people stayed same, but
most of them actually got worse. And that is the problem that
universities are working on.

So using this data, I go
back, just to study one thing. Yeah. Is that a common pattern over
the course of the semester?

And then does it tend
to reset at the start of the next semester, or
is that actually monotonic?

So I don't have a concrete
answer, given the data we had. Because we only recorded
this data for one semester.

We did not do followup studies. But some of our
colleagues who have done some studies
around these symptoms

say that they don't reset. But they sometimes reduce a bit,
and then they increase again.

It's not a monotonic
increase, but it's like a sawtooth with a
general trend to increase.

So using this data, you
can ignore the first week,

the zeroth-week information. Using all this
week's worth of data, we are trying to forecast
whether this student will

feel depressed or have
depression symptoms at the end of the 16 weeks.

So this is the
result that we got. So with one week worth of
information, we are around 75%

accurate, which
could just be noise. But you can see, as we
get more and more data, we are more accurately
able to predict

that this student
will have depression at the end of the semester. So we are forecasting.

And by the middle of the
semester, we are around 92% accurate, which is a great
result. But then it drops.

Does anyone know why
that might happen? Any guesses?

Fall break. Yes, so spring break. This was collected in spring,
so it could be spring break.

Or it could be the
midterms, because that happens in the seventh week. So basically, it's a
sudden change in behavior.

Due to exams or due to
spring break, we don't know. But it's a sudden
change in behavior that the algorithms
did not know about.

And we know in machine learning,
garbage in is garbage out, because the algorithm
did not have information about the context of the user.

It suddenly dropped, and it
almost never recovered from it. Sorry, I just got
another question.

Is it using cumulative
data, or is it using only that week's data? It's cumulative data. That's why you can
see improvement.

But then whatever
noise was injected at around weeks 7 and 8, it
never recovered from that.

Also it goes down
both in weeks 2 and 3. Yeah, so I think that's just
the noise in the signal.

I think initially
it was overfitted. [INAUDIBLE] Or it could be
that the behavior, that because the
students reset, so it

could be that the
initial behavior was more descriptive of their
overall behavior,

like average behavior across
the semester, but hard to tell. And was this holding out
students or holding out--

We, for example-- Hold out students. I see. So you're training the-- Yes. Gotcha. Leave five students out
at a time and average

across all the folds.  So overall, some
of the observations

that we had from
this analysis was that the models are uncertain or
unaware of certain changes that

may happen in our lives. They don't generalize
to similar populations. When you train a model
on one set of population

say, students at
CMU, you try to apply that to students at University
of Washington or Dartmouth,

it does not generalize. In fact, the same model applied
on next year's student at CMU

also does not work that well. So the generalizability
is a huge challenge here. It's still a challenge. I don't have a good
answer to that yet.

And how do we make this
information actionable? So we need to do
personalized interventions. We started some of that work.

But this was around the
time when COVID came, and people's behavior
were very different. So that was another reason
why there was a sudden change

in people's behavior. And the algorithms never
recovered from that. We were looking at phone
data, how the phone is moving,

how many steps they are taking. No one was taking any
steps during COVID. The phone was lying
on the side table.

So the algorithms
did not work at all. And then there was
a proposed solution by the reviewers that why
not just ask the user,
that how they are feeling. And it's not a wrong suggestion.

We actually tried that
in our next study. And then beyond the
college students, not everyone is a student.

Student population is not
same as general population. All students take
very similar classes.

They have breaks
at the same time. So the behaviors are very
homogeneous for the most part.

So to go for a more
heterogeneous population, we started working with patients
who have multiple sclerosis.

Because one of the comorbidities
for that is depression. And we collected similar data.

In this case, we collected
data for 12 weeks. Same sensor data. We got subjective
questionnaires at the beginning

and at the end of the study. But because the practitioner
we were working with

had trust that their
patients will cooperate, we collected finer granularity
ground truth information

from these patients. And beyond that, every
day, three times a day,

we also asked them that,
on a scale of 1 to 5, simple question-- how
depressed do they feel? How fatigued do they feel?

Because we wanted to see if
this information is useful. We collected this data for
more than 100 MS patients.

30% of these patients had
some diagnosis for depression. They came from
all walks of life.

And they were in
different age groups. So some of the
challenges that were here is there is no common
ground, because they

don't go to same classes. They also had varied timelines. They didn't start
on the same day.

It was a rolling recruitment
of these 100 patients. And the best results
we could come up with

was around 50% to 70%, which
is much lower than what we had until then.

This data was also
collected during COVID. So when the stay-at-home
period was there,

that provided us with
some common ground. So we anchored our data
collection around the time

when stay-at-home period began
and when it ended, and used that as the anchor that what
happens to people's behavior

before the period, during
the period, and after. That helped when we did that. So for example, here you can
see that the number of locations

people went suddenly went down. Make sense. Then it slowly recovered. And then the amount of time
we were sleeping increased.

And then slowly that
unfortunately recovered as well. We are not sleeping
as much as we used to sleep during
the stay-at-home period.

So overall, I won't
go into detail, but all the measures
that we recorded, the performance improved
for that 55% to 70%.

Now, we had around 80% results
for almost all the measures. So that common ground helped.

But still that
context is important. In this case, when the algorithm
did not know what happened,

the performance dropped. And I earlier mentioned
that we'll do these EMAs and see if they help or not.

Turns out not bad. Not a lot. If you train a machine
learning model on using data,

if you just ask a person
three times a day, we had great compliance. We had around 90% compliance.

So almost 2.7 EMAs were
responded every day by every patient.

The correlation of the model
that used this information provided by the patient was same
as correlation with step counts.

So just using Fitbit step
count data is enough, it seems, than just
asking this question.

But overall when you
combine all the sources, the performance is
slightly better. So this is without any EMAs.

And then with EMAs, you
can see slight improvement in all of the measures. But the statistically
significant improvement

only came for depression. And it turns out we
don't need all the EMAs. Just one EMA a week was enough.

After that, the
benefit just tapered.

Curious why you think that-- I would think
intuitively you would think that if you ask
somebody that it would

be a much better signal
other than their step count, do people not have a good sense
of how depressed they're doing, or is it the model can't use
that information [INAUDIBLE].

I'm just curious what you think. Yeah, I think there's
a lot of subjectivity. And when you ask someone
how depressed they are,

if that was useful, we
would not have surveys that have 12 and 19 questions. You just have that.

The reasons doctor asks
all those questions is because that gets to
something much more meaningful.

But you can't just keep
asking again and again. There is an argument to be
made that if you just give that 12-question survey, or
nine-whatever-question surveys

at different times a week
in a week, it might work. But we haven't done
that evaluation. That may be.

Just ask one of those questions
one day and another question next day. And when you collate that,
that might be enough.

But because there is a
lot of concerns here, different populations
will react differently, we are doing a
lot of deployments

of the system with
college students in different universities,
in teenage girls, in schools, MS patients
we are continuing

that, with adolescents,
and also cancer survivors. Because all these
populations are

going to bring up
interesting challenges. So for example, with
college students at different
universities, we are also

looking at different cultures. So the cultural
norm at let's say Tsinghua is going
to be very different

from the cultural norm at CMU. So the population models will
be very different as well.

I'm curious. I'm not an expert in
mental health diagnosis,

so just with
depression, I'm curious. It's not a sudden onset issue.

So then, how does an algorithm
draw the separating hyperplane,

so to speak? It seems like maybe you would
need much more longitudinal data to even really have a
chance at predicting this.

Yeah, I think we do
need longitudinal data. With college students it works,
because they are continually

getting worse in many cases. So there are things that
that trajectory provides to the machine learning model.

I'm sorry, I don't bring
much good news here. But for other populations, I
think it is a bit of challenge.

You do need more
longitudinal data. That's why you see
a lot of populations that we are working with is
either students or people who

have some illness, which is
either they are recovering from it so they are
probably getting better, or in some cases getting worse.

But for general
population, it might be much, much harder problem.

So a lot of this
work, where we are trying to figure out what
people's behavior, is the backbone for
the work we do, is

built on practical context and
activity recognition models. And one of the models
that we cheekily came up

with was named Samosa, is part
of some of the consumer devices as well at this point.

We have used this for some of
these data collection efforts.

And one I'll go for
a different domain is around hyperactivity
disorder in children. This is also a situation where
the diagnosis, the management

is very subjective. There are sparse information
that the doctor is using. And here is a quote from a
paper that came out of Canada

a few years ago, that boys
who were born in December were 30% more likely to
receive a diagnosis of ADHD

than boys born in January. And same thing is
true for girls. Any guesses why
that might happen?

Have to do with they cut off
for what grade you get put into

has to do with that. And then you're more mature. Exactly. So when this data was
collected, the cutoff in Canada
